by Sujata Banerjee
Baltimore Sun TV critic
Bill Carter supported the technology, information, and entertainment sections of the television industry to the critics in the
Arts Class in the Evening College last Wednesday.
Technology, often viewed as
the most uninteresting segment
of television, is in reality the
most significant, said Carter.
The advent of cable has affected not only the viewer's far
greater choice of channels but
also the three major networks'
programming.
What formerly drew network
audiences with success must
now be reworked, said Carter.
For example, two-year-old
blockbuster movies on the networks are no longer important
to the viewer who has already
seen them on cable. Networks
have increasingly turned to producing special, "one shot" TV
events such as miniseries.
Cable has also siphoned off
a small element of the highly
educated and affluent television
audience with its cultural programming, as well as teenagers
with programming like MTV.
This situation leaves networks
concentrating their programs
on the mass audience.
Carter said he finds other
facets of technology less important to the medium. He thinks
the home computer boom is essentially a fad and, while it can
serve valuable purposes for

some, the overall population
wil tire of using its screen for
diversion much as the young
people have tired of video
games recently.
The second segment of television, information, is what
Carter said he thinks will keep
the networks from bowing to
cable's power.
"News programs are a huge
informational tool—network
TV can survive as long as their
news is the best," said Carter.
"Handheld cameras have made
it possible for the entire nation
to be witnesses to events like
assassinations. We expect newspeople to be there."
Carter said that overall, TV
news is very professional, but
that accuracy can be a problem.
The pressure for a channel to be
first with a breaking story keeps
reporters from waiting to check
facts, and false information
sometimes results.
Carter spoke tolerantly of the
third area of TV programming,
entertainment. He states there
has been bad TV entertainment
throughout the medium's 30year history and it is not
primarily a recent problem.
Mindless situation comedies
and game shows are developed
to satisfy the typical TV consumer, and Carter thinks the
demand for shows is not always
accurately determined,
The famous Nielsen ratings
are conducted by some 1200
"Nielsen families," a cross section of the American public. A

mechanical monitor records
what time the television set is on
and which station is watched;
who the person watching is,
whether he or she actually likes
the program, and whether anyone is in the room watching at
all is not recorded.
The most perfect form of TV
entertainment is sports, said
Carter.
"They are always done well,
and are entertaining as well as
diverting. And diversion serves
as useful purpose when not
done in excess."
The bottom line in television,

Carter said, is money.
"I think money rules TV
from top to bottom, and this
includes public TV, which has
to bow and scrape for it," he
said.
He said the critic has little
power over the networks, for
criticism has never dislodged a
hit show from the top. A faltering show, however, can gain
strength from supportive criticism; he cites one of his favorite
shows, Hill Street Blues, as an
example of a show kept on for
its good reviews which gradually captured a loyal following.

This country's first major exhibition of ivory as an art form
opened last week at the Walters
Art Gallery. The show, Ivory:
The Sumptuous Art, offers a
comprehensive view of the
material from 4500 BC to 1900
AD. Carvings in ivory represent
some of man's earliest efforts
to form images and has remained a primary sculptural
medium throughout western
history.
The current collection was
put together almost entirely by
Henry Walters, who left his collection and gallery to Baltimore
in 1931. The Walters has one of
the six largest collections in the
world.
The exhibit opens with pictures of ivory carvers and a
display of the sources of ivory.
Most of this collection's ivory
came from elephant tusks and
hippopotamus teeth. But the
tusks of many different animals
have also been used since antiquity, including mammoths,
walruses, narwhals, boar and
warthogs. Ivory-like objects
were made of bone and horn
when ivory was not available.
The exhibit is arranged
chronologically, starting with
Egypt and the ancient Near
East. Among the earliest pieces
in the show are a group of
animals and human figures
made of hippoptamus teeth
from ancient Egypt. These
small figures may have had
magical purposes or perhaps
served as game tokens (about
4500 BC). There are also cosmetic containers, one in the
shape of a duck, and a cosmetic
spoon whose handle is in the
shape of a servant.
Several important pieces of
the show were recently acquired
from the Fortress at Nimrud in
Assyria (9th and 8th centuries
BC). One is a thick plaque that
'depicts a cow nursing a suckling
Icalf, carved in high relief.

in low relief that shows a griffin against the stylized branches
of a sacred tree.

widely known chryselephantine

outstanding Greek pieces is a
small Hellenistic head which
only recently has been identified as Alexander the Great
(356-322 BC).

Hellenistic style, with inlaid
wax panels. The colors are still
intact, as is, surpisingly
enough, the box itself.

combined Greek and Near

reserved for the gods, most

wealthy. The rich tombs of

tools, plaques, appliques and
